newsitem.title: DUBAI: GOLF-WOOSNAM TAKES ONE-STROKE LEAD IN DESERT CLASSIC.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-WOOSNAM TAKES ONE-STROKE LEAD IN DESERT CLASSIC.

text.p: Ian Woosnam produced an eagle-birdie finish to snatch a one-shot lead with a five-under-par 67 in the third round of the Desert Classic on Saturday.
Woosnam pitched his second shot at the 351-yard 17th into the hole on one bounce from 110 yards out for an eagle two, then made a birdie four at the last for a 54-hole total of 203, 13 under par.
"I just had a lucky break at 17 but it's my birthday tomorrow so I need it. I'll be 39 and it will be a nice birthday present if I can win."
Bernhard Langer could not birdie the last and finished one behind after a 68, level with Australian left-hander Richard Green, a 26-year-old from Melbourne who carded a six-under 66.
Defending champion Colin Montgomerie squandered birdie chances on the last three greens among others but emerged with a 68 for sole possession of fourth place on 11 under.
"I missed from eight feet at the 16th, five feet at 17 and from 15 feet at the last. I'd have liked one of them to be a bit closer.
"I left a lot out there today but I'm only two shots back and I haven't given up on this one yet," Europe's number one for the past four years said.
World number one Greg Norman shot 67 and shared fifth spot on 10 under with Irishman Raymond Burns, Swede Klas Eriksson and Briton Malcolm Mackenzie.
"That was the worst score I could have shot," Norman said. "I left a few makeable putts out there.
"But coming over here to play before the Doral Classic in Florida next week was a very good move for me. It has helped with my chipping, my putting and my visualisation," he said.

This is Norman's first full tournament since he won his fifth Australian Open title in November, though he turned out to win a million dollars in the world championship of golf finals early in January.
Spaniard Jose Maria Olazabal continued his fine comeback after 18 months away with chronic foot problems by posting a seven-under-par 65, which drew plaudits from the others.
"It was excellent. He's out there to win. He's walking well and you can see he wants to win, nothing else," Woosnam said.
Olazabal is tied for 11th, five shots off the lead.
"I didn't expect a 65, that's for sure," said Olazabal, who was only two shots off the lead when he finished with the big names still to start.
He expected them to score well and they did. "But I think it would be difficult to win anyway. To win in this situation you have to feel more confident with yourself.
"This is my first tournament and I still don't feel all that comfortable over the ball and when the pressure is there that's when it takes a toll.
"I need a few more weeks and a few more tournaments to get the swing I want and the confidence that is needed to win," he said.
Overnight leader Domingo Hospital of Spain slipped back to a joint 11th after a 74.
The high point of Langer's round came at the long 13th, where he hit a three-iron second left of the green on to a sandy path.

"I had to get it over a little hedge bordering the cart path and under the branches of the palm trees through a gap of about two or three feet and pitch it in the rough with a little backswing and a little roll on it.
"I got it to 15 feet and made the putt for my birdie. That was the highlight of my day," he said.
Green had seven birdies on Saturday including one from 25 feet at the 16th and a 10-footer at the last. He made bogey at the eighth.
